body: Going to the theater is, in many ways, a respectable sort of voyeurism. You pay for your ticket, grab a program and sit down in the dark to peek into the inner lives of complete strangers. It's like flipping through an Architectural Digest of other people's neuroses. ''The Sublet Experiment'' is a play that taps into the thrills of theater's
title: 'The Sublet Experiment' Puts a Different Spin on Home Theater

body: The City Council yesterday approved the first major overhaul of the most popular tax break for apartment building developers, adopting a plan intended to induce them to build tens of thousands of apartments for people other than the well-heeled. The changes, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg supported and which would go into effect in 2008,
title: IN OVERHAUL, CITY SEEKS TO EXPAND LOWER-COST UNITS

body: Twenty-five years after New York State overhauled its property tax system under court pressure, disparities have widened in how New York City taxes real property, with many homeowners in affluent areas disproportionately benefiting from tax breaks, an analysis has found. The analysis, by the city's Independent Budget Office, found that many owners
title: Tax Breaks Seem to Favor Affluent Areas

body: SOMETIMES for all the effort a pizzaiolo puts into his craft, what a good pizza can really use is a good story. Mark Iacono, the man behind Lucali, has one. It starts 30 years ago in Carroll Gardens (and probably in sepia tone). On weekdays, when a young Mr. Iacono went home to his family's brownstone after school, he made a hungry detour to his
title: $25 AND UNDER; Deep Brooklyn Roots and a Passion for Pizza

body: Smith Street in Brooklyn, the center of a restaurant renaissance during the past decade, shows no sign of slowing down. Vietnamese, Italian and French cuisines are among the most recent arrivals. HANCO'S (718) 858-6818; 85 Bergen Street (Smith Street), Boerum Hill; $; Article: 3/8/06. title: CURRENTS: FURNISHINGS; The New Urban Frontier: A Brooklyn Store Opens an Outpost in Manhattan

body: OPENING THIS WEEK KYOTOFU -- Japanese desserts and Japanese-inspired Western desserts, including black sesame sweet tofu, warm chestnut mochi chocolate cake and sansho-pepper tofu cheesecake are on the menu at this sleek dessert cafe, which opened on Monday. It also serves shochu, wines, sakes and cocktails from 5 p.m. daily and stays open until
title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

body: NOT since the Dodgers departed in 1957 has there been a slugfest in Brooklyn like the one over Atlantic Yards. The plan is colossal -- 16 high-rise buildings and an 18,000-seat basketball arena on 22 acres near the borough's busy downtown -- and fans and opponents have matched its magnitude with their own statistics. The developer, Forest City
title: On the Block

body: The boat is called the Empty Vessel. The name was meant to conjure infinite possibility, a floating tabula rasa on the Gowanus Canal in the form of a 63-foot World War II Navy rescue craft. Fifteen months ago, the Empty Vessel journeyed up the canal on a mission both modest and, in this fenced-off, parceled-up city, almost unthinkably grand: to
title: GOWANUS JOURNAL; A Ship of Freethinkers, Hemmed In by Landlords

body: DEAR DIARY: Recently I was at a showing of ''Little Miss Sunshine'' at the Lincoln Square Theater and became increasingly irritated by the guy behind me who kept asking his companion: ''What happened?'' title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: A 22-year-old man was killed when he fell off a roof during a party in Prospect Heights early yesterday morning, the police said. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies In Fall From Roof

body: An article last Sunday about a new hotel near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn misidentified the hotel. It is a Holiday Inn Express, not a Holiday Inn. title: Correction

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS; Far From Tourist Central, a Hotel Opens Its Doors

body: To the Editor: Thank you for ''Tom's World,'' by Roy Hoffman (New York Observed, July 30), the lovely memorial to Tom Mathison, whom I knew when I lived in the West Village in the late 1970's. At that time, the only visitors to the then-decrepit Jane Street pier were Village ''regulars,'' including Tom and me, who came for a daily stroll or jog.
title: A Special Man, With Quiet Dignity

body: Few people ever see Ismile Althaibani's Purple Heart. He keeps the medal tucked away in a dresser. His Marine uniform is stored in a closet. His hair is no longer shaved to the scalp. title: Home From Iraq, and Sorting Out Life as Muslims and Marines

body: For a former home of possibly the country's most notorious mobster, the three-story building with beige siding at 21 Garfield Place in Park Slope, Brooklyn, is totally unremarkable. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; For a Mobster's Home, A Cool $1 Million Price

body: In 1999 the choreographer Yoshiko Chuma happened upon a new obsession: cubes. As a shape, the cube is not particularly sexy, but the use of such movable seven-foot frames has invigorated Ms. Chuma's imagination ever since. title: For Dance, a Cubism of a Different Sort

body: Typically, in New York City, as elsewhere in the United States, a good soccer match is cheered or mourned, but is about as divisive as the metric system. Yesterday was different. title: With Soccer on the Screen, France-Italy Borders Spring Up All Across New York

title: HANDLEBARS; Cheap, Chic and Sociable: The Buzz About Scooters

title: Staten Island Woman, 20, Killed and Four Are Hurt in Accident; Passengers Blame Cabby

title: LIVING IN/Bushwick, Brooklyn; Bargain-Hunting? Stay on the L Train a Little Longer

body: Calling a cheese shop Stinky Bklyn is cheeky. But Patrick Watson, above right, and Michele Pravda, who own this new store at 261 Smith Street (DeGraw Street) in Carroll Gardens, mean it with affection for the borough and the 100 or so cheeses they carry. The two, who also own Smith & Vine, a wine shop across the street, emphasize cheeses from wine
title: FOOD STUFF; In Brooklyn, A New Place For Cheese And Charcuterie

body: PROFESSIONAL chefs will have you think they are calm, with their measured approach to winning ''Iron Chef'' battles and their patient guidance during cooking demos. But in their busy kitchens they're no different from the rest of us: panicked when guests arrive early and dinner is nowhere near done. Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli excepted.
title: Why Not Relax Before Dinner, Too?

title: Side By Side

title: Kissed by Air, Never by Fire

body: WHY GO NOW -- New York has never lacked for colorful characters, evocative settings and random experiences, in sum, fiction's fodder. So much so that it's entirely possible to plan a vacation based solely around
title: GOING TO; Literary New York

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE; On the Menu, Rumors Greatly Exaggerated

title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

title: LIVING IN/Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; A Timeless Neighborhood Grows Even More Popular

author: René Steinke's latest novel, ''Holy Skirts,'' was published in paperback in January.
body: In the 1970's, when my family was visiting from Texas, we took a day trip into Manhattan. Before we left Long Island, my uncle rhapsodized about the Empire State Building; it was taller than almost any other skyscraper; and standing at the top, one could look out and see five states at the same time. Later I overheard him say offhandedly to the
title: 75 YEARS: Voices and Views; 'It Reminds Me More Than Ever Of a Toy'

body: The county of kings received a new queen yesterday. During the early morning hours, the Queen Mary 2, the largest passenger liner ever built, nosed through the Verrazano Narrows and docked at the new Brooklyn Cruise Terminal in Red Hook, shrouded in mist so thick that it obscured Governors Island nearby. It was the final stop on a 38-day cruise
title: New Brooklyn Terminal Shows It's Fit for Queen

title: LIVING ON/ The Lower East Side; A New Page in an Unpredictable Tale

body: Snow means shoveling means money. And yesterday afternoon, two enterprising labor forces converged on the snow-clogged streets of Brooklyn to fight for market share. title: A RECORD SNOWFALL: SNAPSHOTS; Playful, Lucrative or Dreadful: No Two Snow Days Are Alike

title: LIVING IN/Sunset Park, Brooklyn; On the Trail of Brownstones in Brooklyn

title: For Whom Will the Foghorn Blow?

body: BELIEVING that the transit system belongs to us all, four men in Brooklyn opened a bagel store with a subway motif last year, though they were judicious in their choice of effects. title: About New York; Can Bagels Be Intellectual? You'll Have to Ask the M.T.A.

body: Barney and Harriet left their 3,000-square-foot loft in Brooklyn and scampered back to the country. With their lease expired and their acting careers temporarily curbed, they went home to do what everyone in show business does between gigs: sit by the phone and wait for someone to throw them a bone. title: Sit, Stay, Fetch, and Don't Chew the Scenery; Dogs, Horses, Llamas and Even Rats Ply Acting Careers on Broadway

body: FOR many New York City families, January is the cruelest month. It is a time to get seriously claustrophobic in an apartment stocked with young children and the vast plastic undergrowth in which they thrive. It also a time for many to ponder the absurdity (or impossibility) of paying thousands upon thousands of dollars for private-school tuition,
title: Goodbye, Suburbs

body: AFTER a few too many flutes of Champagne and a long night in a haze of crowded bars, another round of drinks may be the last thing running through hangover-clouded minds this morning. title: STREET LEVEL/CARROLL GARDENS; A Bar Of Stiff Drinks Shakes Up A Cocktail Mix
